<ce:section-title>Graphical abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para view="all">Reaction in an aqueous gel medium between a lanthanide ion and the sodium salt of the naphthalene-1,4,5,8-tetra-carboxylic acid can lead to coordination polymers. We report here the synthesis, the crystal structure, the thermal analysis and the calculated porosity of two new coordination polymers involving the lanthanum ion.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Graphical abstract

Reaction in an aqueous gel medium between a lanthanide ion and the sodium salt of the naphthalene-1,4,5,8-tetra-carboxylic acid can lead to coordination polymers. We report here the synthesis, the crystal structure, the thermal analysis and the calculated porosity of two new coordination polymers involving the lanthanum ion.

<ce:section-title>Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para view="all">Reaction in an aqueous gel medium between a lanthanide ion and the sodium salt of the naphthalene-1,4,5,8-tetra-carboxylic acid can lead to coordination polymers. We report here the synthesis, the crystal structure, the thermal analysis and the calculated porosity of two new coordination polymers involving the lanthanum ion.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Abstract

Reaction in an aqueous gel medium between a lanthanide ion and the sodium salt of the naphthalene-1,4,5,8-tetra-carboxylic acid can lead to coordination polymers. We report here the synthesis, the crystal structure, the thermal analysis and the calculated porosity of two new coordination polymers involving the lanthanum ion.

Introduction

For a few years, lanthanide-based coordination polymers have deserved a special attention due to their ability to combine specific physical properties and original crystal structures. There is currently a renewed interest in that field because of the nanotechnologies emergence. Actually, the design of nanoporous open frameworks is a factor of this revival  because these compounds are anticipated to exhibit good efficiency as far as size selective separation, catalysis and gas storage are concerned . These potential applications require materials that do not decompose or collapse upon the removal of the guest molecules. Such materials can be obtained by using aromatic poly-carboxylate ligands. Several lanthanide-based coordination polymers involving benzene-poly-carboxylate ligand have already been described , but potentially porous materials are still rather uncommon . In order to increase the intermetallic distances in these materials, we have undertaken the study of naphthalene-poly-carboxylate-based coordination polymers . The two new lanthanide-containing coordination polymers reported below are part of this study. Both have been obtained by reacting in aqueous gel media a lanthanide chloride with the sodium salt of naphthalene-tetra-carboxylic acid (1,4,5,8-naphthalenetetra-carboxylic acid) (see  ), hereafter symbolized by H4ntc.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(ntc), a rigid multicarboxylate ligand, is of special interest because of its multiple coordination sites, high symmetry and large conjugated π-system. It may lead to molecular assemblies with novel structural motifs and physical properties. However, few reports exist on metal–organic compounds containing (ntc<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup>) .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: H4(ntc), a rigid multicarboxylate ligand, is of special interest because of its multiple coordination sites, high symmetry and large conjugated π-system. It may lead to molecular assemblies with novel structural motifs and physical properties. However, few reports exist on metal-organic compounds containing (ntc4-) .

<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>4H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O]<ce:inf loc="post">∞</ce:inf> and [LaNa[(C<ce:inf loc="post">10</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)(COO)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>](H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>

We describe here their synthesis, their crystal structures and the estimated porosity, and the thermal properties of the compound [LaNa[(C<ce:inf loc="post">10</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)(COO)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>](H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>4H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O]<ce:inf loc="post">∞</ce:inf>.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: To the best of our knowledge the two compounds reported here, with respective chemical formulae [La2[(C10H4)(COO)4](C2O4)(H2O)6 ⋅4H2O]∞ and [LaNa[(C10H4)(COO)4](H2O)7 ⋅4H2O]∞, are the first lanthanum-containing coordination polymers involving this ligand reported so far. We describe here their synthesis, their crystal structures and the estimated porosity, and the thermal properties of the compound [LaNa[(C10H4)(COO)4](H2O)7 ⋅4H2O]∞.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Experimental</ce:section-title><ce:section-title>Synthesis</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">1,4,5,8-Naphthalene-tetra-carboxylic acid (H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>ntc) was purchased from Acros Organics and used without further purification. Tetra-sodium naphthalene-tetra-carboxylate salt is prepared by the addition of four equivalents of sodium hydroxide to a suspension of naphthalene-tetra-carboxylic acid in de-ionized water until complete dissolution of naphthalene-tetra-carboxylic acid. Then, the solution is evaporated to dryness. The solid phase is then put in suspension in ethanol, stirred and refluxed during 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h. After filtration and drying in a desiccator, a white powder of tetra-sodium naphthalene-tetra-carboxylate is obtained. The yield of this synthesis is 90%.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Experimental

Synthesis

1,4,5,8-Naphthalene-tetra-carboxylic acid (H4ntc) was purchased from Acros Organics and used without further purification. Tetra-sodium naphthalene-tetra-carboxylate salt is prepared by the addition of four equivalents of sodium hydroxide to a suspension of naphthalene-tetra-carboxylic acid in de-ionized water until complete dissolution of naphthalene-tetra-carboxylic acid. Then, the solution is evaporated to dryness. The solid phase is then put in suspension in ethanol, stirred and refluxed during 1h. After filtration and drying in a desiccator, a white powder of tetra-sodium naphthalene-tetra-carboxylate is obtained. The yield of this synthesis is 90%.

elements.clean_text:
Single crystal growth

Both coordination polymers were obtained by the slow diffusion of de-ionized aqueous solutions of lanthanum chloride and naphthalene-tetra-carboxylate sodium salts, through an agarose gel bridge, in a U-shaped tube. Agarose was purchased from Acros Organics and gelified according to the established procedures . The La2[(C10H4)(COO)4](C2O4)(H2O)6 ⋅4H2O compound is obtained in a 0.1% agarose gel, while the LaNa[(C10H4)(COO)4](H2O)7 ⋅4H2O one is obtained in a 0.3% agarose gel. After several weeks, colorless single crystals were obtained in both cases.

Anal. Calc. for [La2[(C10H4)(COO)4](C2O4)(H2O)6 ⋅4H2O]∞ (MW=846.16gmol-1): C, 22.71; H, 2.86; O, 41.60; La, 32.83. Found: C, 22.69; H, 2.85; O, 41.61; La, 32.85%.

 Anal. Calc. for [LaNa[(C10H4)(COO)4](H2O)7 ⋅4H2O]∞ (MW=660.24gmol-1): C, 25.47; H, 3.97; O, 46.04; La, 21.04; Na, 3.48. Found: C, 25.45; H, 4.00; O, 46.05; La, 21.05; Na, 3.45%.

Similar IR spectra have been observed for both compounds. They clearly show vibration bands characteristic of the -(O-C-O)- groups around 1560cm-1 and 1490cm-1 confirming the presence of carboxylate groups.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Microcrystalline powder synthesis</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Microcrystalline powder of the lanthanum-containing coordination polymer was obtained by mixing in water stoichiometric amounts of the lanthanum chloride with the tetra-sodium salt of H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>ntc. Precipitation immediately occurred. The white precipitate is filtered and dried in air. The yield of the reaction is almost 100%. This powder has been assumed to be isostructural to the compound [LaNa[(C<ce:inf loc="post">10</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)(COO)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>](H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>4H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O]<ce:inf loc="post">∞</ce:inf> on the basis of its X-ray powder diffraction diagram.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Microcrystalline powder synthesis

Microcrystalline powder of the lanthanum-containing coordination polymer was obtained by mixing in water stoichiometric amounts of the lanthanum chloride with the tetra-sodium salt of H4ntc. Precipitation immediately occurred. The white precipitate is filtered and dried in air. The yield of the reaction is almost 100%. This powder has been assumed to be isostructural to the compound [LaNa[(C10H4)(COO)4](H2O)7 ⋅4H2O]∞ on the basis of its X-ray powder diffraction diagram.

elements.clean_text:
X-ray crystallographic study

Both crystals have been sealed in the glass capillaries for X-ray single crystal data collection in order to avoid potential dehydration. Single crystal was mounted on a Nonius Kappa CCD diffractometer with Mo Kα radiation (λ =0.71073Å). The crystal data collection was performed at room temperature.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">A crystal-to-detector distance of 25.0<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mm was used, and data collection strategy (determination and optimization of the detector and goniometer positions) was performed with the help of the <ce:small-caps>collect</ce:small-caps> program  to measure Bragg reflections of the unique volume in reciprocal space.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: A crystal-to-detector distance of 25.0mm was used, and data collection strategy (determination and optimization of the detector and goniometer positions) was performed with the help of the collect program  to measure Bragg reflections of the unique volume in reciprocal space.

elements.clean_text:
Unique reflections were indexed, Lorentz-polarization was corrected and then integrated by the denzo program of the KappaCCD software package .

Absorption corrections were performed using the facilities  included in the wingx program suite .

Structure determinations were performed with the solving program sir97  that revealed all the non-hydrogen atoms. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically using the shelxl program . Hydrogen atoms bound to the organic ligand were localized at ideal positions. Hydrogen atoms of water molecules have not been localized. Crystal and final structure refinement data of the two compounds are listed in  .

X-ray powder diffraction

Diagrams have been collected using a Panalytical X'Pert Pro diffractometer with an X'celerator detector. The typical recording conditions were 40kV, 40mA for Cu Kα (λ =1.542Å), the diagrams were recorded in θ/θ mode in 60min between 5° and 75° (8378 measurements) with a step size of 0.0084° in 2θ and a scan time of 50s. The calculated patterns were produced using the powdercell and winplotr software programs .

<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1.542<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å), the diagrams were recorded in 2<ce:italic>θ</ce:italic> mode in 5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>min between 5° and 70° (4189 measurements) with a step size of 0.02° in 2<ce:italic>θ</ce:italic> and a scan time of 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>s.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Temperature-dependent X-ray powder diffraction experiments have been performed under nitrogen for [LaNa[(C10H4)(COO)4](H2O)7 ⋅4H2O]∞ between room temperature and 900°C using a Panalytical PW1050/80 goniometer equipped with an Anton-Parr HTK 1200 furnace. The operating conditions were the following : 40kV, 25mA for Cu Kα (λ =1.542Å), the diagrams were recorded in 2θ mode in 5min between 5° and 70° (4189 measurements) with a step size of 0.02° in 2θ and a scan time of 10s.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Thermal analysis</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Thermogravimetric and thermal differential analysis were performed in a platinum crucible under nitrogen atmosphere between room temperature and 1000<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C with a heating rate of 5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>min<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>, using a Perkin–Elmer Pyris-Diamond thermal analyzer. At 1000<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, the gas is switched to oxygen and the temperature is maintained during 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h in order to complete the oxidation.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Thermal analysis

Thermogravimetric and thermal differential analysis were performed in a platinum crucible under nitrogen atmosphere between room temperature and 1000°C with a heating rate of 5°Cmin-1, using a Perkin-Elmer Pyris-Diamond thermal analyzer. At 1000°C, the gas is switched to oxygen and the temperature is maintained during 1h in order to complete the oxidation.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Infrared spectra</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Infrared (IR) samples were prepared as KBr pellets and spectra were obtained in the 400–4000<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> range using a Perkin–Elmer Paragon 1000C spectrophotometer.</ce:para><ce:section-title>Results and discussion</ce:section-title><ce:section-title>Crystal structure of compound [La<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>[(C<ce:inf loc="post">10</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)(COO)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>](C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>4H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O]<ce:inf loc="post">∞</ce:inf>
</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Single crystal X-ray analysis of [La<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(ntc)(ox)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>4H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O]<ce:inf loc="post">∞</ce:inf> reveals the presence of oxalate (ox<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup>) ligand in the coordination environment of the La<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> ions. Because oxalate is not present in the starting reaction mixture, it must come from decomposition of (ntc<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup>). A similar situation has already been observed in other systems  involving one of the lightest lanthanide ion. Although the reaction mechanism still remains unclear, the oxalate may be formed through an <ce:italic>in situ</ce:italic> metal-mediated oxidation-hydrolysis reaction of (ntc<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup>). The lanthanum ion probably acts as a Lewis acid to catalyze the reaction.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Infrared spectra

Infrared (IR) samples were prepared as KBr pellets and spectra were obtained in the 400-4000cm-1 range using a Perkin-Elmer Paragon 1000C spectrophotometer.

Results and discussion

Crystal structure of compound [La2[(C10H4)(COO)4](C2O4)(H2O)6 ⋅4H2O]∞ 

Single crystal X-ray analysis of [La2(ntc)(ox)(H2O)6 ⋅4H2O]∞ reveals the presence of oxalate (ox2-) ligand in the coordination environment of the La3+ ions. Because oxalate is not present in the starting reaction mixture, it must come from decomposition of (ntc4-). A similar situation has already been observed in other systems  involving one of the lightest lanthanide ion. Although the reaction mechanism still remains unclear, the oxalate may be formed through an in situ metal-mediated oxidation-hydrolysis reaction of (ntc4-). The lanthanum ion probably acts as a Lewis acid to catalyze the reaction.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">It is noticeable that there is only one coordination mode in this structure. As it can be seen in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig1"></ce:float-anchor>, the La(III) ion is coordinated by ten oxygen atoms forming a distorted bi-capped dodecahedron. Four out of them come from two (ntc<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup>) ligands, three out of them come from two oxalate ligands, and the three last come from the coordination water molecules. All carboxyl groups of 1,2,4,5-benzenetetracarboxylic acid are deprotonated, in agreement with the IR spectrum which shows no strong absorption peaks around 1700<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> for –COOH. Each carboxylate group of (ntc<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup>) adopts a bidentate chelating mode, chelating one La(III) ion. Each ox<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> acts as a μ<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>-bridge linking four lanthanum centers.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: It is noticeable that there is only one coordination mode in this structure. As it can be seen in  , the La(III) ion is coordinated by ten oxygen atoms forming a distorted bi-capped dodecahedron. Four out of them come from two (ntc4-) ligands, three out of them come from two oxalate ligands, and the three last come from the coordination water molecules. All carboxyl groups of 1,2,4,5-benzenetetracarboxylic acid are deprotonated, in agreement with the IR spectrum which shows no strong absorption peaks around 1700cm-1 for -COOH. Each carboxylate group of (ntc4-) adopts a bidentate chelating mode, chelating one La(III) ion. Each ox2- acts as a μ4-bridge linking four lanthanum centers.

The structure can be described as planes spreading in the (a,b) plane (see  ). In these planes, along the b-axis, lanthanum ions and ligands alternate.

The planes are bonded to each other by the [Na(H2O)6]+ entities leading to a 3D molecular network (see  ). Spreading parallel to the a-axis, the structure shows cavities in which the crystallization water molecules are localized.

<ce:float-anchor refid="fig6"></ce:float-anchor>).</ce:para><ce:para view="all">(i) First a total dehydration occurs between room temperature and 130<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C leading to an anhydrous compound with chemical formula LaNaC<ce:inf loc="post">14</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>. The dehydration is accompanied by a loss of crystallinity. (ii) The resulting powder is stable from 130<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C to 450<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C and does not rehydrate when exposed to moisture. (iii) At last, above 450<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, the ligand decomposes leading, at high temperature, to the two oxides La<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> and Na<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Thermal analysis of compound [LaNa[(C10H4)(COO)4](H2O)7 ⋅4H2O]∞ 

The thermal behavior of this compound has been studied by thermal analysis (TGA/TDA) and by TDXD (see  ).

(i) First a total dehydration occurs between room temperature and 130°C leading to an anhydrous compound with chemical formula LaNaC14H4O8. The dehydration is accompanied by a loss of crystallinity. (ii) The resulting powder is stable from 130°C to 450°C and does not rehydrate when exposed to moisture. (iii) At last, above 450°C, the ligand decomposes leading, at high temperature, to the two oxides La2O3 and Na2O.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">These experiments clearly demonstrate that the molecular network is irreversibly destroyed at very low temperature upon heating. This feature is not surprising because the stability of the tri-dimensional network is insured by [Na(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup> entities, which are destroyed upon dehydration. Furthermore, the thermal analysis indicates that the dehydration occurs in one stage. Therefore, it seems impossible to evacuate crystallization water molecules and coordinated water molecules independently by heating.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: These experiments clearly demonstrate that the molecular network is irreversibly destroyed at very low temperature upon heating. This feature is not surprising because the stability of the tri-dimensional network is insured by [Na(H2O)6]+ entities, which are destroyed upon dehydration. Furthermore, the thermal analysis indicates that the dehydration occurs in one stage. Therefore, it seems impossible to evacuate crystallization water molecules and coordinated water molecules independently by heating.

<ce:float-anchor refid="fig8"></ce:float-anchor>), it appears that the compound can host molecules with a kinetic radius smaller than 1.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, for instance, He (1.3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) or H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (1.45<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å). <ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Anal. Calc. for LaNa[(C10H4)(COO)4](H2O)7, (MW=587.9gmol-1): C, 28.57; H, 3.06; O, 40.83; La, 23.63; Na, 3.91. Found: C, 28.5; H, 3.1; O, 40.83; La, 23.6; Na, 3.9%.

Similar IR spectra have been observed for both hydrated and partially dehydrated compounds. The partial dehydration has been checked and confirmed by thermogravimetric measurements.

At last, the partially dehydrated compound reversibly binds water when exposed to moisture.

Estimated porosity of compound [LaNa[(C10H4)(COO)4](H2O)7]∞ 

In order to evaluate the porosity of [LaNa[(C10H4)(COO)4](H2O)7]∞, we have formally removed the crystallization water molecules from the crystal structure of [LaNa[(C10H4)(COO)4](H2O)7 ⋅4H2O]∞ and applied a computational method  based on Connolly's algorithm . Thanks to this method, the porosity of a partially dehydrated material can be calculated on the basis of its crystal structure. Furthermore, this method allows obtaining the maximal kinetic radius a guest molecule can present for being hosted by the structure. In this case (see  ), it appears that the compound can host molecules with a kinetic radius smaller than 1.5Å, for instance, He (1.3Å) or H2 (1.45Å). The estimated potential porosity, calculated with 1.45Å as probe sphere radius, is actually 757m2 g-1.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Conclusions and outlook</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">We have reported here the two first examples of lanthanum-containing coordination polymers involving 1,4,5,8-naphthalene-tetra-carboxylate as ligand. One of them, namely [LaNa[(C<ce:inf loc="post">10</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)(COO)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>](H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>4H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O]<ce:inf loc="post">∞</ce:inf> is 3D and presents channels that host guest water molecules. Unfortunately it has been proven here that this solid cannot be thermally activated because it decomposes upon heating. We have thus synthesized by freeze-drying a second compound, namely [LaNa[(C<ce:inf loc="post">10</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)(COO)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>](H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">∞</ce:inf>, isostructural to the former and exhibiting channels free of guest water molecule. Thanks to Connolly’s approach, we have estimated its potential porosity which is not negligible. This study confirms the validity of our approach. Up to now, 1,4,5,8-naphthalene-tetra-carboylate-based coordination polymers have been only obtained with La<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> ions. It would be very interesting to extend the families to other lanthanide ions exhibiting catalytic or optical properties. We are currently working along this line.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions and outlook

We have reported here the two first examples of lanthanum-containing coordination polymers involving 1,4,5,8-naphthalene-tetra-carboxylate as ligand. One of them, namely [LaNa[(C10H4)(COO)4](H2O)7 ⋅4H2O]∞ is 3D and presents channels that host guest water molecules. Unfortunately it has been proven here that this solid cannot be thermally activated because it decomposes upon heating. We have thus synthesized by freeze-drying a second compound, namely [LaNa[(C10H4)(COO)4](H2O)7]∞, isostructural to the former and exhibiting channels free of guest water molecule. Thanks to Connolly's approach, we have estimated its potential porosity which is not negligible. This study confirms the validity of our approach. Up to now, 1,4,5,8-naphthalene-tetra-carboylate-based coordination polymers have been only obtained with La3+ ions. It would be very interesting to extend the families to other lanthanide ions exhibiting catalytic or optical properties. We are currently working along this line.

CCDC 675650 and 675651 contain the supplementary crystallographic data for [La2[(C10H4)(COO)4](C2O4)(H2O)6 ⋅4H2O]∞ and [LaNa[(C10H4)(COO)4](H2O)7 ⋅4H2O]∞. These data can be obtained free of charge from The Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif.

<ce:section-title>Experimental</ce:section-title><ce:section-title>Synthesis</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">1,4,5,8-Naphthalene-tetra-carboxylic acid (H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>ntc) was purchased from Acros Organics and used without further purification. Tetra-sodium naphthalene-tetra-carboxylate salt is prepared by the addition of four equivalents of sodium hydroxide to a suspension of naphthalene-tetra-carboxylic acid in de-ionized water until complete dissolution of naphthalene-tetra-carboxylic acid. Then, the solution is evaporated to dryness. The solid phase is then put in suspension in ethanol, stirred and refluxed during 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h. After filtration and drying in a desiccator, a white powder of tetra-sodium naphthalene-tetra-carboxylate is obtained. The yield of this synthesis is 90%.</ce:para><ce:section-title>Single crystal growth</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Both coordination polymers were obtained by the slow diffusion of de-ionized aqueous solutions of lanthanum chloride and naphthalene-tetra-carboxylate sodium salts, through an agarose gel bridge, in a U-shaped tube. Agarose was purchased from Acros Organics and gelified according to the established procedures . The La<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>[(C<ce:inf loc="post">10</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)(COO)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>](C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>4H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O compound is obtained in a 0.1% agarose gel, while the LaNa[(C<ce:inf loc="post">10</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)(COO)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>](H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>4H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O one is obtained in a 0.3% agarose gel. After several weeks, colorless single crystals were obtained in both cases.</ce:para><ce:section-title>Microcrystalline powder synthesis</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Microcrystalline powder of the lanthanum-containing coordination polymer was obtained by mixing in water stoichiometric amounts of the lanthanum chloride with the tetra-sodium salt of H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>ntc. Precipitation immediately occurred. The white precipitate is filtered and dried in air. The yield of the reaction is almost 100%. This powder has been assumed to be isostructural to the compound [LaNa[(C<ce:inf loc="post">10</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)(COO)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>](H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>4H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O]<ce:inf loc="post">∞</ce:inf> on the basis of its X-ray powder diffraction diagram.</ce:para><ce:para view="all">Temperature-dependent X-ray powder diffraction experiments have been performed under nitrogen for [LaNa[(C<ce:inf loc="post">10</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)(COO)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>](H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>4H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O]<ce:inf loc="post">∞</ce:inf> between room temperature and 900<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C using a Panalytical PW1050/80 goniometer equipped with an Anton-Parr HTK 1200 furnace. The operating conditions were the following : 40<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>kV, 25<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mA for Cu Kα (<ce:italic>λ</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1.542<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å), the diagrams were recorded in 2<ce:italic>θ</ce:italic> mode in 5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>min between 5° and 70° (4189 measurements) with a step size of 0.02° in 2<ce:italic>θ</ce:italic> and a scan time of 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>s.</ce:para>

Experimental

Synthesis

1,4,5,8-Naphthalene-tetra-carboxylic acid (H4ntc) was purchased from Acros Organics and used without further purification. Tetra-sodium naphthalene-tetra-carboxylate salt is prepared by the addition of four equivalents of sodium hydroxide to a suspension of naphthalene-tetra-carboxylic acid in de-ionized water until complete dissolution of naphthalene-tetra-carboxylic acid. Then, the solution is evaporated to dryness. The solid phase is then put in suspension in ethanol, stirred and refluxed during 1h. After filtration and drying in a desiccator, a white powder of tetra-sodium naphthalene-tetra-carboxylate is obtained. The yield of this synthesis is 90%.

Single crystal growth

Both coordination polymers were obtained by the slow diffusion of de-ionized aqueous solutions of lanthanum chloride and naphthalene-tetra-carboxylate sodium salts, through an agarose gel bridge, in a U-shaped tube. Agarose was purchased from Acros Organics and gelified according to the established procedures . The La2[(C10H4)(COO)4](C2O4)(H2O)6 ⋅4H2O compound is obtained in a 0.1% agarose gel, while the LaNa[(C10H4)(COO)4](H2O)7 ⋅4H2O one is obtained in a 0.3% agarose gel. After several weeks, colorless single crystals were obtained in both cases.

Microcrystalline powder synthesis

Microcrystalline powder of the lanthanum-containing coordination polymer was obtained by mixing in water stoichiometric amounts of the lanthanum chloride with the tetra-sodium salt of H4ntc. Precipitation immediately occurred. The white precipitate is filtered and dried in air. The yield of the reaction is almost 100%. This powder has been assumed to be isostructural to the compound [LaNa[(C10H4)(COO)4](H2O)7 ⋅4H2O]∞ on the basis of its X-ray powder diffraction diagram.

Temperature-dependent X-ray powder diffraction experiments have been performed under nitrogen for [LaNa[(C10H4)(COO)4](H2O)7 ⋅4H2O]∞ between room temperature and 900°C using a Panalytical PW1050/80 goniometer equipped with an Anton-Parr HTK 1200 furnace. The operating conditions were the following : 40kV, 25mA for Cu Kα (λ =1.542Å), the diagrams were recorded in 2θ mode in 5min between 5° and 70° (4189 measurements) with a step size of 0.02° in 2θ and a scan time of 10s.

Anal. Calc. for C14H10O8Na4 (MW=392gmol-1): C, 42.8; H, 1.0; O, 32.7; Na, 23.5. Found: C, 42.9; H, 1.1; O, 32.5; Na, 23.5%.

Hydrated lanthanide chlorides were prepared from the corresponding oxides according to literature methods . Lanthanide oxides were purchased from STREM Chemicals and used without further purification.

 Anal. Calc. for [La2[(C10H4)(COO)4](C2O4)(H2O)6 ⋅4H2O]∞ (MW=846.16gmol-1): C, 22.71; H, 2.86; O, 41.60; La, 32.83. Found: C, 22.69; H, 2.85; O, 41.61; La, 32.85%.

 Anal. Calc. for [LaNa[(C10H4)(COO)4](H2O)7 ⋅4H2O]∞ (MW=660.24gmol-1): C, 25.47; H, 3.97; O, 46.04; La, 21.04; Na, 3.48. Found: C, 25.45; H, 4.00; O, 46.05; La, 21.05; Na, 3.45%.

Similar IR spectra have been observed for both compounds. They clearly show vibration bands characteristic of the -(O-C-O)- groups around 1560cm-1 and 1490cm-1 confirming the presence of carboxylate groups.

Thermal analysis

Thermogravimetric and thermal differential analysis were performed in a platinum crucible under nitrogen atmosphere between room temperature and 1000°C with a heating rate of 5°Cmin-1, using a Perkin-Elmer Pyris-Diamond thermal analyzer. At 1000°C, the gas is switched to oxygen and the temperature is maintained during 1h in order to complete the oxidation.

Thermal analysis of compound [LaNa[(C10H4)(COO)4](H2O)7 ⋅4H2O]∞ 

The thermal behavior of this compound has been studied by thermal analysis (TGA/TDA) and by TDXD (see  ).

(i) First a total dehydration occurs between room temperature and 130°C leading to an anhydrous compound with chemical formula LaNaC14H4O8. The dehydration is accompanied by a loss of crystallinity. (ii) The resulting powder is stable from 130°C to 450°C and does not rehydrate when exposed to moisture. (iii) At last, above 450°C, the ligand decomposes leading, at high temperature, to the two oxides La2O3 and Na2O.

 Anal. Calc. for LaNa[(C10H4)(COO)4](H2O)7, (MW=587.9gmol-1): C, 28.57; H, 3.06; O, 40.83; La, 23.63; Na, 3.91. Found: C, 28.5; H, 3.1; O, 40.83; La, 23.6; Na, 3.9%.

Similar IR spectra have been observed for both hydrated and partially dehydrated compounds. The partial dehydration has been checked and confirmed by thermogravimetric measurements.

At last, the partially dehydrated compound reversibly binds water when exposed to moisture.

Estimated porosity of compound [LaNa[(C10H4)(COO)4](H2O)7]∞ 

In order to evaluate the porosity of [LaNa[(C10H4)(COO)4](H2O)7]∞, we have formally removed the crystallization water molecules from the crystal structure of [LaNa[(C10H4)(COO)4](H2O)7 ⋅4H2O]∞ and applied a computational method  based on Connolly's algorithm . Thanks to this method, the porosity of a partially dehydrated material can be calculated on the basis of its crystal structure. Furthermore, this method allows obtaining the maximal kinetic radius a guest molecule can present for being hosted by the structure. In this case (see  ), it appears that the compound can host molecules with a kinetic radius smaller than 1.5Å, for instance, He (1.3Å) or H2 (1.45Å). The estimated potential porosity, calculated with 1.45Å as probe sphere radius, is actually 757m2 g-1.

decomposition temperature.type: gradual removal of coordinated water molecules
